guide:gentext.p:
The genus Agaricus is best known to most people as it is the common white button mushroom sold in stores. The large brown Portabella and Crimini mushrooms are different strains of this same cultivated species.
A few members of this genus are good edibles, but others are poisonous, so great care is needed in identification.

Separating the different Agaricus species is often difficult. Both young and mature fruitbodies are helpful to see changes in gill color, staining reactions, and ring development. Odors and differences in habitat are also important.

guide:similarGenera.comments: The parasol mushrooms, Lepiota and related genera, are related to Agaricus but they have white or pale green spore prints.
